raw_text:
Big guns ease through in San Jose
 
 Top-seeded Americans Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi survived minor scares to reach the last eight of the SAP Open.
 
 Agassi endured early problems against left-handed Dane Kenneth Carlsen before sealing a 7-5 6-1 victory. And world number three Roddick dropped a set to Korean player Hyung-Taik Lee, before pulling out a 6-3 3-6 6-2 win in San Jose, California. Seventh seed Jurgen Melzer came through 6-3 6-3 against Xavier Malisse - winner in Delray Beach last week. Frenchman Cyril Saulnier, meanwhile, fired 19 aces to secure a 6-1 7-6 win over Czech qualifier Tomas Zib.
 
 Roddick broke a racket in frustration in the third game of the second set. and afterwards was unimpressed with his form. "I'm not playing great," he said. "But I'm through and I'm going to keep battling. "A lot of people are under the assumption that it's easy to play well every week and it's not." It is the 12th time in 13 appearances at the event that Agassi, now 34, has progressed to the quarter-final stage. He came from 0-40 down in the opening game to hold serve and gradually wore Carlsen down after attacking his backhand. Agassi also employed several lobs and charged to the net to unsettle the 31-year-old Dane, ranked 88th in the world. "As the match went on, I got real patient and waited for my opportunities and felt pretty good," said Agassi.
llama3.2:1b:
Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi survived minor scares to reach the last eight of the SAP Open.

Roddick lost a set to Dane Kenneth Carlsen before winning 6-3 3-6 6-2.
Agassi also dropped sets, but eventually won 7-5 6-1 against Kenichi Takahata and defeated Hyung-Taik Lee in two sets.

Seventh seed Jurgen Melzer won 6-3 6-3 against Xavier Malisse.
Cyril Saulnier fired 19 aces to win 6-1 7-6 over Tomas Zib.
llama3.2:3b: American players Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi advanced to the quarterfinals of the SAP Open. Roddick defeated Hyung-Taik Lee after dropping a set, while Agassi beat Kenneth Carlsen in five sets. Seventh seed Jurgen Melzer also won, and Cyril Saulnier secured six aces to beat Tomas Zib 6-1.
gemma2:2b: Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi both advanced to the quarterfinals of the SAP Open in San Jose after overcoming some early challenges. Roddick won a tight match against Lee despite dropping a set, while Agassi defeated Carlsen after trailing at one point. Jurgen Melzer also progressed easily, and Cyril Saulnier secured his victory with strong serving.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
### Summary:

In San Jose, California, top-seeded American Andy Roddick defeated Danish left-hander Andre Agassi 7-5, 6-1, while Frenchman Cyril Saulnier won 6-3, 6-3 against Xan Malisse in the SAP Open. Roddick faced difficulties early and lost a set to Korean player Hyung-Taik Lee. Agassi emerged victorious with his third win of the day, securing a 7-5, 6-1 victory over Dane Kenneth Carlsen. Both players also secured their top-three finishes at the event.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Top-seeded American players Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi reached the quarterfinals of the San Jose event at the SAP Open. Agassi won against left-handed Dane Kenneth Carlsen, while Roddick overcame Korean player Hyung-Taik Lee in a tough match despite losing a set to Melzer. Agassi's 34th appearance at the tournament saw him overcome a deficit after being down by two sets and break point early.
qwen2.5:3b: Top-seeded Americans Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi advanced to the last eight of the SAP Open after overcoming minor challenges. Agassi won against a left-handed opponent from Denmark in a tough match, while Roddick staged an upset victory over a Korean player after dropping one set. Seventh seed Melzer also reached the quarter-finals with a win against Malisse. Saulnier defeated Zib in straight sets, despite breaking his racket during the second set. Agassi has now advanced to the quarter-final stage at this event for 12 consecutive appearances.
opencoder:1.5b:
"Big guns ease through in San Jose", as they survived minor scares to reach the last eight of the SAP Open.
The top-seeded American players Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi both fought against Dane Kenneth Carlsen before securing a 7-5 victory in San Jose, California. Seventh seed Jurgen Melzer came through 6-3 6-3 against Xavier Malisse - winner in Delray Beach last week.
Agassi pulled out a 6-2 win over Czech qualifier Tomas Zib by scoring first in the game, which secured a 7-5 victory and dropped a set to Hyung Taik Lee. Frenchman Cyril Saulnier fired 19 aces to secure a 7-6 win over the Czech match.
Roddick broke a racket in frustration in the third game of the second set after which he was unimpressed with his form. "I'm not playing great," he said. "But I'm through and I'm going to keep battling." It's been Agassi's 12th time in 13 appearances at the event that he has progressed to the quarter-final stage.
The 34-year-old player, having played 0-40 down in the opening game, came from 88th place in the world. "As the match went on, I got real patient and waited for my opportunities and felt pretty good," Agassi said. This all began with Roddick's injury at the home match against Dane, but he eventually recovered and continued battling.

Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi made it to the last eight of the SAP Open at San Jose. Agassi, now 34, faced a tough challenge from Dane Carlsen but won 7-5 6-1, using powerful shots like lobs to set up Sendy and finish off the match. tinyllama:1.1b: With top seeded Americans Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi through to the last eight of the SAO Open in San Jose, California, American top-seed Jürgen Melzer withstood a minor scare from South Korean player Hyung-Tae Kim before pulling out a 6-3 3-6 6-2 victory, while Frenchman Fabrice Sauquin fired 19 ace serves to secure his place in the quarterfinals. In contrast, Czech qualifier Tomas Zibelius struggled at times but managed to break twice and keep serving in a tiebreaker that went to 5-all against American Michael Chandler in the second set. Despite Roddick's 6-3 7-6 win over the Frenchman, he was not on top form, while Agassi's win over Carlos David Duran showed his consistency and ability to put pressure on opponents.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The SAP Open has produced several notable results so far this year, with top-seeded Americans Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi advancing to the last eight following recent rounds of play. Despite facing minor challenges, Roddick managed to emerge victorious against left-handed Dane Kenneth Carlsen in the opening round while defeating Hyung-Taik Lee in a closely contested match. Meanwhile, fifth seed Jurgen Melzer also displayed impressive form, securing a 6-3 6-3 victory over Xavier Malisse, who had previously defeated him in Delray Beach. Second seed Cyril Saulnier also managed to overcome a losing position, clinching a 19-aided 6-1 7-6 win against Czech qualifier Tomas Zib. Roddick broke a racket during the third game of the second set but remained unimpressed with his performance. "I'm not playing great," he admitted. However, he remains confident in his ability to perform well and is now through to the quarter-final stage of the SAP Open.
phi:2.7b: The top-seeded American player, Andy Roddick, was close to losing but managed to pull out a 6-2 win against Korean player Hyung-Taik Lee in San Jose after suffering from some early problems. Andre Agassi also survived a scare by winning 7-5 and 7-6 against Dane Kenneth Carlsen. The tournament is the 12th time in 13 appearances for Agassi, who has been under pressure to perform well as he was 34 years old. He defeated Carlsen through patience and strategy after attacking his backhand aggressively.

Roddick dropped a set to Korean player Hyung-Taik Lee, but won in three sets. Seventh seed Jurgen Melzer came through 6-3 6-3 against Xavier Malisse, who won in Delray Beach last week. Frenchman Cyril Saulnier fired 19 aces to secure a 6-1 7-6 win over Czech qualifier Tomas Zib.

Agassi, a 34-year-old veteran with 12 previous quarter-final appearances at this event, defeated Danish player Kenneth Carlsen 7-5, 6-1 after starting slowly and battling back from a 0-40 deficide in the first game. Roddick, ranked third, lost his opening set to South Korean Hyung-Taik Lee but regrouped for a 6-3, 3-6, 6-2 victory. Jurgen Melzer and Cyril Saulnier also secured their spots in the quarter-finals with straight-set wins against Xavier Malisse and Tomas Zib, respectively. Roddick expressed frustration about his play but remained determined to continue his tournament run. Agassi praised his patience and ability to seize opportunities, while Roddick noted that consistent high performance is not easy.
